utterances: So you see that?
(Through translator) We know lots of Iraqis here who have had their cars smashed by Jordanians.
Why do they lump us all together, not all Iraqis are bad, maybe a few.
It's different now.
Several miles down the road back toward Amman stands an old refugee camp from the early days of the war.
Jordanians hope it's not a sign of more refugees to come.
(SOUNDBITE OF TRAFFIC)
A steady stream of trucks inches towards the border gate, some loaded with goods, but many empty on their way to pick up cars in Jordan to bring back to Iraq.
32-year-old driver Sad Kalil Haraj (ph) says these days the news is as bad as ever.
(Speaking foreign language)
He says the road is no safer.
It still costs too much money and bribes to travel safely and even then that's no guarantee.
If it weren't for the money he has tied up in his truck, he'd look for another job.
(SOUNDBITE OF ELECTRICAL MANUFACTURING PLANT)

Manager Hasham Al-Kaises (ph) says since 2003, however, $15 to $20 million in annual contracts with Iraq have all but evaporated and the company's been forced to close production lines and lay off more than 500 workers.
2006 is worse than 2005, 2005 is worse than 2004 and it is going downhill.
This year, since the beginning of January, it's been 90 days, the borders with Jordan being closed for about good 60 days.
You cannot do anything.
You used to pay at the border $300 now we pay $2,000.
That's bribes for who's in charge of the Iraqi border at that time.
It's getting worse and it's getting worse.
With Iraq still making up 90 percent of Kaises's market he's become an avid follower of developments there.
He sees recently announced talks between Iran and the U.S.
on stabilizing Iraq as another opportunity for Tehran to increase its influence in the region.
Like many Arabs, Kaises expects the Iranians to outmaneuver the Americans.
You know they're intelligent, actually they're, you know, dictating to the U.S.
government.
I know your U.S.
now is the biggest country, but I feel they've got the Americans by the short and curlies, as they say.
In his real estate office in the upscale Abdun neighborhood of the capital, Rael al Jafaari (ph) says the rising prices were breathtaking.
In Abdun, we used to buy 1,000 square meters for about $200,000 to $250,000.
These days, you'll pay a million.
It really went up real high.
Some prices went up between 200 to 500 percent.
Meanwhile, security issues continue to flare.
Last month, the military tribunal sentenced five Islamist militants to terms of up to life in prison for plotting to attack tourist destinations.
Some analysts are beginning to wonder if this new, more dangerous Jordan is here to stay.
I think this will destroy Jordan, and it could even destroy Jordanian politics.
Columnist Abdula Aburamin says the flood of Iraqis in Jordan is hurting on two levels.
Poor Iraqis are competing with Jordanians for entrylevel jobs and the rich ones have driven up prices.
His biggest worry is that in their rising frustration, ordinary Jordanians may turn a more sympathetic ear to radical Islam, something he says is already happening in the south.
Before Iraqi war, the al-Qaida movement in Jordan was very weak.
People hid them.
They are bad people, they are extreme.
After Iraqi war, they became to look to them as heroes, as fighters, they are fighting the American army, and they are defending our nation.
He says, to a growing number of people all across the Middle East, as well as in Europe and Asia, it's now obvious that what the U.S.
policies have done is to bring the bloodshed to their homelands.
This is true, I mean, everybody in the region is feeling it, but did that stop the terrorists from hitting somewhere else in the world?
We saw what happened in Spain, we saw what happened in England.
I don't think it did.
Shukri believes King Abdullah may be able to keep a lid on the increasing economic, social and security pressures buffeting Jordan, but for how long?

It's not good for any country to be living next to a country where practically there is a continuous conflict, and three years is a long time, long time, and we hope to God that this will somehow be controlled and simmer down before they end up in a state of civil war.
Peter Kenyon, NPR News.
Relations between Syria and Lebanon are at an all-time low.
This week Gebran Tueni was assassinated; he was a prominent Lebanese critic of the Syrian government.
A UN investigator has already implicated Syria in the murder of another Lebanese politician.
As NPR's Deborah Amos reports, Damascus and Beirut are trading heated threats and accusations.

It is a packed house every night at the Rameeda Theater(ph) in Damascus for a new play called ""Stand Up, Sit Down, Silence."" The authors poke fun at the UN investigation, but the broad farce is most insulting to prominent Lebanese politicians who are well-known here as critics of the Syrian regime.
The sexually explicit humor gets laughs every night.
(Soundbite of play performance; laughter)
(Foreign language spoken)
The Syrian-Lebanese relations have deteriorated dramatically over the past actually few weeks.
Marwan Kabalan, a professor at Damascus University, says Syria has tightened the border.
Syrian workers are coming home from Lebanon.
Tensions have never been higher.

The Syrian government believes now that Lebanon is helping the American in order to bring down the regime, because this is for the first time a Lebanese politician would call for regime change in Damascus.
Lebanese calls for toppling the Syrian regime came this week after the assassination of Gebran Tueni, a prominent critic of Damascus, killed by a powerful car bomb in Beirut.
Four prominent Lebanese critics of Syria have also been killed this year.
(Soundbite of funeral activities)
Come on, Bashar, you have to kill everybody from Lebanon here.
And the world is full of opportunities for change, but he was full of rhetoric.
Well, there are more.
It's not clear that they're necessarily connected to this guy.
There was a second arrest in connection with the guy.
That was a civilian student however.

But officials say three other soldiers are being investigated for far-right criminal activity, and German military intelligence is also investigating 280 complaints about far-right military activity, in other words, within the military - for example, German soldiers exhibiting Nazi paraphernalia or calling out Sieg Heil or posting Nazi sentiments on social media, like this one in which a soldier wrote in a WhatsApp group chat (reading) missing since 1945.
Adolf Hitler, please check in.
Germany needs you.
OK, not to be taken lightly.
So what does the defense minister plan to do about any of this?
Well, she's launched an in-depth investigation, and she's told reporters this is going to be very painful and delve deep in order to fully root out any problem and rectify it.

I should point out that this is one of several military scandals that von der Leyen has had to deal with this year, including sexual abuse and hazing, which I think is part of why she's so angry with the military leadership at the moment.
All right, so given German history, anything to do with its military and the far-right would be, I would imagine, incredibly sensitive.
How is this unfolding in Germany?
How are people reacting?
Well, interestingly enough, there's actually a huge backlash against her being so harsh with the military leadership.
They feel that this sweeping criticism shouldn't be done in open as she's been doing it.
But most important is the fact that Chancellor Angela Merkel is actually backing her despite all of this, so it seems that she's coming from a strong political position.
NPR's Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson reporting in Berlin.
Soraya, thanks.
You're welcome, Rachel.
The White House announced what could be a major foreign policy move last week that, amidst the news on North Korea and Iran, didn't get a lot of attention.
The Trump administration says it will review all aid that it gives to South Sudan as the 8-year-old nation spirals into further chaos.
The U.S.
is the largest donor for humanitarian programs in the country, so any potential change could have an enormous impact.
John Prendergast is the founding director of the Enough Project, which seeks to stop genocide in Sudan.
He's also a former State Department official on the Africa Desk, among other government posts.
And he joins us now.
Welcome to the program.
Thank you so much.
So let's start with - how bad are things in South Sudan right now?

All the worst sort of manifestations of war are unfolding today in South Sudan - you know, recruitment of child soldiers, rape as an instrument of conflict and war, the pushing - the displacement of people - the forced displacement of people - you would call ethnic cleansing in many parts of the country - leading to the deterioration of humanitarian conditions to the point of near famine.
The U.S.
said in a very strong statement this past week that it will not continue in a partnership with leaders who are only interested in what it calls perpetrating an endless war.
You were part of the brain trust that helped in the creation of South Sudan, which the United States was heavily involved in.
Why do you think this administration is threatening to cut all humanitarian programs?
Well, I think, you know, at this point, the feeling is that this is a government that's lost all of its legitimacy.
This is a government that no longer, really - it can be conceived of in conventional political terms.
This is not a government that supplies services to its people.
It's not a government that builds infrastructure, it's not a government that provides security and adjudicates disputes.
It's a looting machine.
It's a kleptocracy.
It's a den of thieves.
Would cutting all the aid work?
Oh, no. I think this is a point of leverage that we think we have, but it would only work if people actually cared about the welfare of their own population.

So what I fear is, if we actually followed through - the United States actually followed through with cutting off humanitarian assistance, the government of South Sudan would point at the starving babies and say, look what the United States did.
South Sudan gained independence in 2011, as we mentioned, with U.S.
help.
Was it a mistake when you now look at what has happened there?
